description: From Ancient Greek αὐστηρός (austērós, “bitter, harsh”), having the specific meaning "making the tongue dry" (originally used of fruits, wines), related to αὔω (aúō, “to singe”), αὖος (aûos, “dry”).

adjectives.description: austere (comparative austerer or more austere, superlative austerest or most austere)

entries.meaning: Grim or severe in manner or appearance
examples: The headmistress was an austere old woman.

entries.meaning: Lacking decoration; trivial; not extravagant or gaudy
examples: The interior of the church was as austere as the parishioners were dour.
